pages.title: Your account and profile on GitHub
pages.intro: Make {% data variables.product.product_name %} work best for you by adjusting the settings for your user account, personalizing your profile page, and managing the notifications you receive for activity on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}.

pages.title: Managing subscriptions and notifications on GitHub
pages.intro: You can specify how to receive notifications, the repositories you are interested in, and the types of activity you want to hear about.

pages.title: Managing subscriptions for activity on GitHub
pages.intro: To maintain sustainable notification workflows, understand and regularly review your subscriptions.

pages.title: Managing your subscriptions
pages.intro: To help you manage your notifications efficiently, there are several ways to unsubscribe.

pages.title: Viewing your subscriptions
pages.intro: To understand where your notifications are coming from and your notifications volume, we recommend reviewing your subscriptions and watched repositories regularly.

pages.title: About notifications
pages.intro: Notifications provide updates about the activity on {% data variables.product.product_location %} that you've subscribed to. You can use the notifications inbox to customize, triage, and manage your updates.

pages.title: Configuring notifications
pages.intro: Choose the type of activity on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} that you want to receive notifications for and how you want these updates delivered.

pages.title: Setting up notifications
pages.intro: To improve the relevance of your notifications and simplify your triaging workflow, set up your notifications to match your priorities.

pages.title: Customizing a workflow for triaging your notifications
pages.intro: To create an ideal workflow for triaging your notifications, you can adapt and customize these example workflows.

pages.title: Viewing and triaging notifications
pages.intro: To optimize your notifications workflow, you can customize how you view and triage notifications.

pages.title: Managing notifications from your inbox
pages.intro: Use your inbox to quickly triage and sync your notifications across email{% ifversion fpt or ghes or ghec %} and mobile{% endif %}.

pages.title: Triaging a single notification
pages.intro: When you review and investigate a single notification, you have several triaging options that are optimized for the detailed notification view.

pages.title: About your organization's profile
pages.intro: Your organization's profile page shows basic information about your organization.

pages.title: About your profile
pages.intro: Your profile page tells people the story of your work through the repositories you're interested in, the contributions you've made, and the conversations you've had.

pages.title: Customizing your profile
pages.intro: You can customize your profile so that other people can get a better sense of who you are and the work you do.

pages.title: Managing your profile README
pages.intro: You can add a README to your {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} profile to tell other people about yourself.

pages.title: Personalizing your profile
pages.intro: You can share information about yourself with other {% data variables.product.product_name %} users by setting a profile picture and adding a bio to your profile.

pages.title: Pinning items to your profile
pages.intro: You can pin gists and repositories to your profile so other people can quickly see your best work.

pages.title: Setting up and managing your GitHub profile
pages.intro: You can customize your GitHub profile and manage your contribution graph.

pages.title: Managing contribution graphs on your profile
pages.intro: Your contributions, including commits, proposed pull requests, and opened issues, are displayed on your profile so people can easily see the work you've done.

pages.title: Publicizing or hiding your private contributions on your profile
pages.intro: Your {% data variables.product.product_name %} profile shows a graph of your repository contributions over the past year. You can choose to show anonymized activity from {% ifversion fpt or ghes or ghec %}private and internal{% else %}private{% endif %} repositories{% ifversion fpt or ghes or ghec %} in addition to the activity from public repositories{% endif %}.

pages.title: Sending enterprise contributions to your GitHub.com profile
pages.intro: You can highlight your work on {% data variables.product.prodname_enterprise %} by sending the contribution counts to your {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom_the_website %} profile.

pages.title: Showing an overview of your activity on your profile
pages.intro: You can enable the activity overview section on your profile to give viewers more context about the types of contributions you make.

pages.title: Troubleshooting commits on your timeline
pages.intro: You can view details for commits from your profile's timeline. If you don't see commits you expect on your profile or can't find commit details from your profile page, the commit date and the commit author date may be different.

pages.title: Viewing contributions on your profile
pages.intro: Your {% data variables.product.product_name %} profile shows off {% ifversion fpt or ghes or ghec %}your pinned repositories as well as{% endif %} a graph of your repository contributions over the past year.

pages.title: Why are my contributions not showing up on my profile?
pages.intro: Learn common reasons that contributions may be missing from your contributions graph.

pages.title: Setting up and managing your GitHub user account
pages.intro: You can manage settings in your GitHub user account including email preferences, collaborator access for personal repositories, and organization memberships.

pages.title: Managing access to your personal repositories
pages.intro: You can give people collaborator access to repositories owned by your personal account.

pages.title: Inviting collaborators to a personal repository
pages.intro: You can {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}invite users to become{% else %}add users as{% endif %} collaborators to your personal repository.

pages.title: Maintaining ownership continuity of your user account's repositories
pages.intro: You can invite someone to manage your user owned repositories if you are not able to.

pages.title: Removing a collaborator from a personal repository
pages.intro: When you remove a collaborator from your project, they lose read/write access to your repository. If the repository is private and the person has created a fork, then that fork is also deleted.

pages.title: Removing yourself from a collaborator's repository
pages.intro: If you no longer want to be a collaborator on someone else's repository, you can remove yourself.

pages.title: Adding an email address to your GitHub account
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.product_name %} allows you to add as many email addresses to your account as you like. If you set an email address in your local Git configuration, you will need to add it to your account settings in order to connect your commits to your account. For more information about your email address and commits, see "[Setting your commit email address](/articles/setting-your-commit-email-address/)."

pages.title: Blocking command line pushes that expose your personal email address
pages.intro: If you've chosen to keep your email address private when performing web-based operations, you can also choose to block command line pushes that may expose your personal email address.

pages.title: Changing your primary email address
pages.intro: You can change the email address associated with your user account at any time.

pages.title: Managing email preferences
pages.intro: You can add or change the email addresses associated with your account on {% ifversion ghae %}{% data variables.product.product_name %}{% else %}{% data variables.product.product_location %}{% endif %}. You can also manage emails you receive from {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Managing marketing emails from GitHub
pages.intro: In addition to notifications and account emails, {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} occasionally sends marketing emails with news and information about our products. If you unsubscribe from existing marketing emails, you won't be included in future campaigns unless you change your {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} email settings.

pages.title: Remembering your GitHub username or email
pages.intro: Are you signing in to {% data variables.product.product_location %} for the first time in a while? If so, welcome back! If you can't remember your {% data variables.product.product_name %} user account name, you can try these methods for remembering it.

pages.title: Setting a backup email address
pages.intro: Use a backup email address as an additional destination for security-relevant account notifications{% ifversion not ghae %} and to securely reset your password if you can no longer access your primary email address{% endif %}.

pages.title: Setting your commit email address
pages.intro: You can set the email address that is used to author commits on {% data variables.product.product_location %} and on your computer.

pages.title: Types of emails GitHub sends
pages.intro: There are several types of emails you can receive from {% data variables.product.product_name %}, including notifications, account information, customer research invitations, and marketing communications.

pages.title: About your personal dashboard
pages.intro: You can visit your personal dashboard to keep track of issues and pull requests you're working on or following, navigate to your top repositories and team pages, stay updated on recent activities in organizations and repositories you're subscribed to, and explore recommended repositories.

pages.title: Best practices for leaving your company
pages.intro: Changing jobs is a fact of life. If you use your GitHub user account for both personal *and* work purposes, there are a few things to keep in mind when you leave your company or organization.

pages.title: Changing your GitHub username
pages.intro: You can change the username for your account on {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}{% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom_the_website %}{% elsif ghes %}{% data variables.product.product_location %} if your instance uses built-in authentication{% endif %}.

pages.title: Converting a user into an organization
pages.intro: You can convert your user account into an organization. This allows more granular permissions for repositories that belong to the organization.

pages.title: Deleting your user account
pages.intro: You can delete your {% data variables.product.product_name %} user account at any time.

pages.title: Managing user account settings
pages.intro: You can change several settings for your personal account, including changing your username and deleting your account.

pages.title: Integrating Jira with your personal projects
pages.intro: You can integrate Jira Cloud with your user account to scan commits and pull requests, creating relevant metadata and hyperlinks in any mentioned Jira issues.

pages.title: Managing access to your user account's project boards
pages.intro: As a project board owner, you can add or remove a collaborator and customize their permissions to a project board.

pages.title: Managing accessibility settings
pages.intro: You can disable character key shortcuts on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} in your accessibility settings.

pages.title: Managing security and analysis settings for your user account
pages.intro: You can control features that secure and analyze the code in your projects on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}.

pages.title: Managing the default branch name for your repositories
pages.intro: You can set the default branch name for new repositories that you create on {% data variables.product.product_location %}.

pages.title: Managing your tab size rendering preference
pages.intro: You can manage the number of spaces a tab is equal to for your user account.

pages.title: Managing your theme settings
pages.intro: You can manage how {% data variables.product.product_name %} looks to you by setting a theme preference that either follows your system settings or always uses a light or dark mode.

pages.title: Merging multiple user accounts
pages.intro: If you have separate accounts for work and personal use, you can merge the accounts.

pages.title: Permission levels for a user account repository
pages.intro: A repository owned by a user account has two permission levels: the repository owner and collaborators.

pages.title: Permission levels for user-owned project boards
pages.intro: A project board owned by a user account has two permission levels: the project board owner and collaborators.

pages.title: What does the 'Available for hire' checkbox do?
pages.intro: Use the **Available for hire** checkbox to view GitHub Jobs posts within GitHub.

pages.title: About organization membership
pages.intro: You can become a member of an organization to collaborate with coworkers or open-source contributors across many repositories at once.

pages.title: Accessing an organization
pages.intro: To access an organization that you're a member of, you must sign in to your personal user account.

pages.title: Managing your membership in organizations
pages.intro: If you're a member of an organization, you can publicize or hide your membership, view other people's roles, and remove yourself from the organization.

pages.title: Managing your scheduled reminders
pages.intro: Get reminders in Slack when you or your team have pull requests waiting for review.

pages.title: Publicizing or hiding organization membership
pages.intro: If you'd like to tell the world which organizations you belong to, you can display the avatars of the organizations on your profile.

pages.title: Removing yourself from an organization
pages.intro: If you're an outside collaborator or a member of an organization, you can leave the organization at any time.

pages.title: Requesting organization approval for OAuth Apps
pages.intro: Organization members can request that an owner approve access to organization resources for {% data variables.product.prodname_oauth_app %}.

pages.title: Viewing people's roles in an organization
pages.intro: You can view a list of the people in your organization and filter by their role. For more information on organization roles, see "[Roles in an organization](/organizations/managing-peoples-access-to-your-organization-with-roles/roles-in-an-organization)."
pages.permissions: Organization members can see people's roles in the organization.

pages.intro: You can use secrets to allow {% data variables.product.prodname_codespaces %} to access a private image registry

pages.intro: This article describes guidance for a disaster recovery scenario, when a whole region experiences an outage due to major natural disaster or widespread service interruption.

pages.intro: You can use the Command Palette feature of {% data variables.product.prodname_vscode %} to access many commands in Codespaces.

pages.intro: You can change the type of machine that's running your codespace, so that you're using resources appropriate for work you're doing.

pages.intro: {% data variables.product.prodname_codespaces %} is a dedicated environment for you. pages.intro: You can personalize {% data variables.product.prodname_codespaces %} by using a `dotfiles` repository on {% data variables.product.product_name %} or by using Settings Sync.

pages.intro: You can set your default region in the {% data variables.product.prodname_github_codespaces %} profile settings page to personalize where your data is held.

pages.intro: You can set your default timeout for {% data variables.product.prodname_codespaces %} in your personal settings page.

pages.intro: You can develop in your codespace directly in {% data variables.product.prodname_vscode %} by connecting the {% data variables.product.prodname_github_codespaces %} extension with your account on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.intro: You can work with {% data variables.product.prodname_github_codespaces %} directly from your command line by using `gh`, the {% data variables.product.product_name %} command line interface.

pages.intro: After making changes to a file in your codespace you can quickly commit the changes and push your update to the remote repository.

pages.title: About wikis
pages.intro: You can host documentation for your repository in a wiki, so that others can use and contribute to your project.

pages.title: Adding or editing wiki pages
pages.intro: You can add and edit wiki pages directly on {% data variables.product.product_name %} or locally using the command line.

pages.title: Changing access permissions for wikis
pages.intro: Only repository collaborators can edit a {% ifversion fpt or ghec or ghes %}public{% endif %} repository's wiki by default, but you can allow anyone with an account on {% ifversion ghae %}{% data variables.product.product_name %}{% else %}{% data variables.product.product_location %}{% endif %} to edit your wiki.

pages.title: Creating a footer or sidebar for your wiki
pages.intro: You can add a custom sidebar or footer to your wiki to provide readers with more contextual information.

pages.title: Disabling wikis

pages.title: Editing wiki content
pages.intro: You can add images and links to content in your wiki, and use some supported MediaWiki formats.

pages.title: Documenting your project with wikis
pages.intro: You can use a wiki to share detailed, long-form information about your project.

pages.title: Viewing a wiki's history of changes
pages.intro: Because wikis are Git repositories, every change you make is a commit that you can view.

pages.title: Building communities
pages.intro: Learn best practices for moderating and setting up collaborative, safe, and effective communities using GitHubs community-tested tools.

pages.title: Blocking a user from your organization
pages.intro: Organization owners can block a user to remove the user's ability to collaborate in the organization's repositories.

pages.title: Blocking a user from your personal account
pages.intro: You can block a user to deny them access to your activity and repositories, and to prevent them from sending you notifications.

pages.title: Maintaining your safety on GitHub
pages.intro: To build a positive and safe environment for yourself and the community for your project on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}, you can block and unblock users and report disruptive content.

pages.title: Reporting abuse or spam
pages.intro: You can report behavior and content that violates community guidelines and terms.

pages.title: Unblocking a user from your organization
pages.intro: Organization owners can unblock a user who was previously blocked, restoring their access to the organization's repositories.

pages.title: Unblocking a user from your personal account
pages.intro: If you've mended fences with a {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} user you've blocked, you can unblock their account.

pages.title: Viewing users who are blocked from your organization
pages.intro: You can view a list of all users whom you or other owners have blocked from your organization. If a user was blocked for a specific amount of time, you can see the amount of time they were blocked for.

pages.title: Viewing users you've blocked from your personal account
pages.intro: You can view a list of all users you've blocked from your personal account.

pages.title: Moderating comments and conversations
pages.intro: Moderating conversations creates a welcoming community for all contributors to your project by promoting healthy collaboration and de-escalating conflict. You can apply your community's code of conduct to discussions by viewing reported content, editing and deleting comments, and locking conversations.

pages.title: Limiting interactions for your user account
pages.intro: You can temporarily enforce a period of limited activity for certain users in all public repositories owned by your user account.
pages.permissions: Anyone can limit interactions for their own user account.

pages.title: Limiting interactions in your organization
pages.intro: You can temporarily enforce a period of limited activity for certain users in all public repositories owned by your organization.
pages.permissions: Organization owners can limit interactions in an organization.

pages.title: Limiting interactions in your repository
pages.intro: You can temporarily enforce a period of limited activity for certain users on a public repository.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions to a repository can temporarily limit interactions in that repository.

pages.title: Locking conversations
pages.intro: Repository owners and collaborators, and people with write access to a repository, can lock conversations on issues, pull requests, and commits permanently or temporarily to defuse a heated interaction.

pages.title: Managing disruptive comments
pages.intro: You can {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}hide, edit,{% else %}edit{% endif %} or delete comments on issues, pull requests, and commits.

pages.title: Managing how contributors report abuse in your organization's repository
pages.intro: You can allow contributors to report disruptive behavior directly to repository maintainers.

pages.title: Managing reported content in your organization's repository
pages.intro: After a contributor reports disruptive content in a repository, repository maintainers can view and manage the report.

pages.title: Tracking changes in a comment
pages.intro: You can view the edit history of a comment or delete sensitive information from the edit history of a comment.

pages.title: About community management and moderation
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} offers tools that help repository maintainers establish and enforce standards of behavior in their communities on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom_the_website %}.

pages.title: About community profiles for public repositories
pages.intro: Repository maintainers can review their public repository's community profile to learn how they can help grow their community and support contributors. Contributors can view a public repository's community profile to see if they want to contribute to the project.

pages.title: Accessing a project's community profile
pages.intro: View a public repository's community profile to check on a project's health and decide if you want to contribute.

pages.title: Adding a code of conduct to your project
pages.intro: Adopt a code of conduct to define community standards, signal a welcoming and inclusive project, and outline procedures for handling abuse.

pages.title: Adding a license to a repository
pages.intro: You can include an open source license in your repository to make it easier for other people to contribute.

pages.title: Adding support resources to your project
pages.intro: You can create a SUPPORT file to let people know about ways to get help with your project.

pages.title: Creating a default community health file

pages.intro: Learn tips for managing your projects on {% data variables.product.company_short %}.

pages.intro: Display the information you need by changing the layout, grouping, sorting, and filters in your project.

pages.intro: Build customized projects to track your work in {% data variables.product.company_short %}.

pages.title: About milestones
pages.intro: You can use milestones to track progress on groups of issues or pull requests in a repository.

pages.title: Associating milestones with issues and pull requests
pages.intro: You can associate similar issues and pull requests with a milestone to better track their progress.

pages.title: Creating and editing milestones for issues and pull requests
pages.intro: You can create a milestone to track progress on groups of issues or pull requests in a repository.

pages.title: Filtering issues and pull requests by milestone
pages.intro: Issues and pull requests can be filtered based on the milestone they're associated with. Once you've [associated an issue or pull request with a milestone](/articles/associating-milestones-with-issues-and-pull-requests), you can find items based on their milestones. Within a milestone, you can prioritize issues and pull requests.

pages.title: Using labels and milestones to track work
pages.intro: Use labels and milestones to categorize and track work on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}.

pages.title: Managing labels
pages.intro: You can classify {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}issues, pull requests, and discussions{% else %}issues and pull requests{% endif %} by creating, editing, applying, and deleting labels.
pages.permissions: {% data reusables.enterprise-accounts.emu-permission-repo %}

pages.title: Viewing your milestone's progress
pages.intro: In order to track your milestones, you'll want to get a better understanding of how many open issues and pull requests are remaining.

pages.title: GitHub Packages Documentation
pages.intro: Learn to safely publish and consume packages, store your packages alongside your code, and share your packages privately with your team or publicly with the open source community. You can also automate your packages with {% data variables.product.prodname_actions %}.

pages.title: About permissions for GitHub Packages
pages.intro: Learn about how to manage permissions for your packages.

pages.title: Configuring a package's access control and visibility
pages.intro: Choose who has read, write, or admin access to your container image and the visibility of your container images on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}.

pages.title: Connecting a repository to a package
pages.intro: You can connect a repository to a container image on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}.

pages.title: Deleting a package
pages.intro: You can delete a version of a {% ifversion not ghae %}private{% endif %} package using GraphQL or on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Deleting and restoring a package
pages.intro: Learn how to delete or restore a package.

pages.title: Learn GitHub Packages
pages.intro: You can find out more about using packages in GitHub, including publishing new packages to {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %}, view and install existing packages, and, in special circumstances, delete existing packages.

pages.title: Installing a package
pages.intro: You can install a package from {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} and use the package as a dependency in your own project.
pages.permissions: You can install any package that you have permission to view.

pages.title: Introduction to GitHub Packages
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} is a software package hosting service that allows you to host your software packages privately {% ifversion ghae %} for specified users or internally for your enterprise{% else %}or publicly{% endif %} and use packages as dependencies in your projects.

pages.title: Publishing a package
pages.intro: You can publish a package to {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} to make the package available for others to download and re-use.
pages.permissions: Anyone with write permissions for a repository can publish a package to that repository.

pages.title: Viewing packages
pages.intro: You can see details about packages published to a repository, and narrow results by organization or user.
pages.permissions: You must have at least read permissions to view a package.

pages.title: About GitHub Packages and GitHub Actions
pages.intro: Learn the fundamentals of managing packages through your {% data variables.product.prodname_actions %} workflows.

pages.title: Example workflows for publishing a package
pages.intro: To help you get started with your own custom workflows, review some example workflows for publishing packages.

pages.title: Managing GitHub packages using GitHub Actions workflows
pages.intro: You can safely publish and consume packages by building custom workflows that can also build, test, and deploy your code.

pages.title: Publishing and installing a package with GitHub Actions
pages.intro: You can configure a workflow in {% data variables.product.prodname_actions %} to automatically publish or install a package from {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %}.

pages.title: Quickstart for GitHub Packages
pages.intro: Publish to {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} with {% data variables.product.prodname_actions %}.

pages.intro: Learn how to use a supported {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} registry.
