pages.intro: Docker images previously stored in the Docker registry are being automatically migrated to the {% data variables.product.prodname_container_registry %}.

pages.title: Working with the Apache Maven registry
pages.intro: You can configure Apache Maven to publish packages to {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} and to use packages stored on {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} as dependencies in a Java project.

pages.title: Working with the Container registry
pages.intro: You can store and manage Docker and OCI images in the {% data variables.product.prodname_container_registry %}, which uses the package namespace `https://ghcr.io`.

pages.title: Working with the Docker registry
pages.intro: {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}The Docker registry has now been replaced by the {% data variables.product.prodname_container_registry %}.{% else %}You can push and pull your Docker images using the {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} Docker registry, which uses the package namespace `https://docker.pkg.github.com`.{% endif %}

pages.title: Working with the Gradle registry
pages.intro: You can configure Gradle to publish packages to the {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} Gradle registry and to use packages stored on {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} as dependencies in a Java project.

pages.title: Working with the npm registry
pages.intro: You can configure npm to publish packages to {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} and to use packages stored on {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} as dependencies in an npm project.

pages.title: Working with the NuGet registry
pages.intro: You can configure the `dotnet` command-line interface (CLI) to publish NuGet packages to {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} and to use packages stored on {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} as dependencies in a .NET project.

pages.title: Working with the RubyGems registry
pages.intro: You can configure RubyGems to publish a package to {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} and to use packages stored on {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} as dependencies in a Ruby project with Bundler.

pages.title: About custom domains and GitHub Pages
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} supports using custom domains, or changing the root of your site's URL from the default, like `octocat.github.io`, to any domain you own.

pages.title: Configuring a custom domain for your GitHub Pages site
pages.intro: You can customize the domain name of your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: Managing a custom domain for your GitHub Pages site
pages.intro: You can set up or update certain DNS records and your repository settings to point the default domain for your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site to a custom domain.

pages.title: Troubleshooting custom domains and GitHub Pages
pages.intro: You can check for common errors to resolve issues with custom domains or HTTPS for your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: Verifying your custom domain for GitHub Pages
pages.intro: You can increase the security of your custom domain and avoid takeover attacks by verifying your domain.

pages.title: About GitHub Pages
pages.intro: You can use {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} to host a website about yourself, your organization, or your project directly from a repository on {% ifversion ghae %}{% data variables.product.product_name %}{% else %}{% data variables.product.product_location %}{% endif %}.

pages.title: Adding a theme to your GitHub Pages site with the theme chooser
pages.intro: You can add a theme to your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site to customize your sites look and feel.
pages.shortTitle: Add theme to a Pages site

pages.title: Changing the visibility of your GitHub Pages site
pages.intro: You can manage access control for your project site by publishing the site publicly or privately.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions for a repository can change the visibility of a {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: Configuring a publishing source for your GitHub Pages site
pages.intro: If you use the default publishing source for your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site, your site will publish automatically. You can also choose to publish your site from a different branch or folder.
pages.permissions: People with admin or maintainer permissions for a repository can configure a publishing source for a {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: Creating a custom 404 page for your GitHub Pages site
pages.intro: You can display a custom 404 error page when people try to access nonexistent pages on your site.

pages.title: Creating a GitHub Pages site
pages.intro: You can create a {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site in a new or existing repository.

pages.title: Getting started with GitHub Pages
pages.intro: You can set up a basic {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site for yourself, your organization, or your project.

pages.title: Securing your GitHub Pages site with HTTPS
pages.intro: HTTPS adds a layer of encryption that prevents others from snooping on or tampering with traffic to your site. You can enforce HTTPS for your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site to transparently redirect all HTTP requests to HTTPS.

pages.title: Unpublishing a GitHub Pages site
pages.intro: You can unpublish your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site so that the site is no longer available.
pages.permissions: People with admin or maintainer permissions for a repository can unpublish a {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: Using submodules with GitHub Pages
pages.intro: You can use submodules with {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} to include other projects in your site's code.

pages.title: GitHub Pages Documentation
pages.intro: You can create a website directly from a repository on {% ifversion ghae %}{% data variables.product.product_name %}{% else %}{% data variables.product.product_location %}{% endif %}.

pages.title: Quickstart for GitHub Pages
pages.intro: You can use {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} to showcase some open source projects, host a blog, or even share your rsum. This guide will help get you started on creating your next website.

pages.title: About GitHub Pages and Jekyll
pages.intro: Jekyll is a static site generator with built-in support for {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %}.

pages.title: About Jekyll build errors for GitHub Pages sites
pages.intro: If Jekyll encounters an error building your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site locally or on {% data variables.product.product_name %}, you'll receive an error message with more information.

pages.title: Adding a theme to your GitHub Pages site using Jekyll
pages.intro: You can personalize your Jekyll site by adding and customizing a theme.

pages.title: Adding content to your GitHub Pages site using Jekyll
pages.intro: You can add a new page or post to your Jekyll site on {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %}.

pages.title: Creating a GitHub Pages site with Jekyll
pages.intro: You can use Jekyll to create a {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site in a new or existing repository.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions for a repository can create a {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site with Jekyll.

pages.title: Setting up a GitHub Pages site with Jekyll
pages.intro: You can use Jekyll, a popular static site generator, to further customize your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: Setting a Markdown processor for your GitHub Pages site using Jekyll
pages.intro: You can choose a Markdown processor to determine how Markdown is rendered on your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: Testing your GitHub Pages site locally with Jekyll
pages.intro: You can build your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site locally to preview and test changes to your site.

pages.title: Troubleshooting Jekyll build errors for GitHub Pages sites
pages.intro: You can use Jekyll build error messages to troubleshoot problems with your {% data variables.product.prodname_pages %} site.

pages.title: About merge conflicts
pages.intro: Merge conflicts happen when you merge branches that have competing commits, and Git needs your help to decide which changes to incorporate in the final merge.

pages.title: Addressing merge conflicts
pages.intro: If your changes have merge conflicts with the base branch, you must address the merge conflicts before you can merge your pull request's changes.

pages.title: Resolving a merge conflict on GitHub
pages.intro: You can resolve simple merge conflicts that involve competing line changes on GitHub, using the conflict editor.

pages.title: Resolving a merge conflict using the command line
pages.intro: You can resolve merge conflicts using the command line and a text editor.

pages.title: About status checks
pages.intro: Status checks let you know if your commits meet the conditions set for the repository you're contributing to.

pages.title: Collaborating on repositories with code quality features
pages.intro: Workflow quality features like statuses, {% ifversion ghes %}pre-receive hooks, {% endif %}protected branches, and required status checks help collaborators make contributions that meet conditions set by organization and repository administrators.

pages.title: Working with pre-receive hooks
pages.intro: *Pre-receive hooks* enforce rules for contributions before commits may be pushed to a repository.

pages.title: About collaborative development models
pages.intro: The way you use pull requests depends on the type of development model you use in your project. You can use the fork and pull model or the shared repository model.

pages.title: Getting started
pages.intro: Learn about the {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} flow and different ways to collaborate on and discuss your projects.

pages.title: About pull request merges
pages.intro: You can [merge pull requests](/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/incorporating-changes-from-a-pull-request/merging-a-pull-request) by retaining all the commits in a feature branch, squashing all commits into a single commit, or by rebasing individual commits from the `head` branch onto the `base` branch.

pages.title: Adding a pull request to the merge queue
pages.intro: If merge queues are enabled for the repository, you can add your pull requests to the merge queue once all the required checks have passed. {% data variables.product.product_name %} will merge the pull requests for you.

pages.title: Automatically merging a pull request
pages.intro: You can increase development velocity by enabling auto-merge for a pull request so that the pull request will merge automatically when all merge requirements are met.

pages.title: Closing a pull request
pages.intro: You may choose to *close* a pull request without [merging it into the upstream branch](/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/incorporating-changes-from-a-pull-request/merging-a-pull-request). This can be handy if the changes proposed in the branch are no longer needed, or if another solution has been proposed in another branch.

pages.title: Incorporating changes from a pull request
pages.intro: You can propose changes to your work on {% data variables.product.product_name %} through pull requests. Learn how to create, manage, and merge pull requests.

pages.title: Merging a pull request
pages.intro: Merge a pull request into the upstream branch when work is completed. Anyone with push access to the repository can complete the merge.

pages.title: Reverting a pull request
pages.intro: You can revert a pull request after it's been merged to the upstream branch.

pages.title: Collaborating with pull requests
pages.intro: Track and discuss changes in issues, then propose and review changes in pull requests.

pages.title: About branches
pages.intro: Use a branch to isolate development work without affecting other branches in the repository. Each repository has one default branch, and can have multiple other branches. You can merge a branch into another branch using a pull request.

pages.title: About comparing branches in pull requests
pages.intro: Pull requests display diffs to compare the changes you made in your topic branch against the base branch that you want to merge your changes into.

pages.title: About pull requests
pages.intro: Pull requests let you tell others about changes you've pushed to a branch in a repository on {% data variables.product.product_name %}. Once a pull request is opened, you can discuss and review the potential changes with collaborators and add follow-up commits before your changes are merged into the base branch.

pages.title: Changing the base branch of a pull request
pages.intro: After a pull request is opened, you can change the base branch to compare the changes in the pull request against a different branch.

pages.title: Changing the stage of a pull request
pages.intro: You can mark a draft pull request as ready for review{% ifversion fpt or ghae or ghes or ghec %} or convert a pull request to a draft{% endif %}.
pages.permissions: People with write permissions to a repository and pull request authors can change the stage of a pull request.

pages.title: Committing changes to a pull request branch created from a fork
pages.intro: You can commit changes on a pull request branch that was created from a fork of your repository with permission from the pull request creator.
pages.shortTitle: Commit to PR branch from fork

pages.title: Creating a pull request from a fork
pages.intro: You can create a pull request to propose changes you've made to a fork of an upstream repository.
pages.permissions: Anyone with write access to a repository can create a pull request from a user-owned fork. {% data reusables.enterprise-accounts.emu-permission-propose %}
pages.shortTitle: Create a PR from a fork

pages.title: Creating a pull request
pages.intro: Create a pull request to propose and collaborate on changes to a repository. These changes are proposed in a *branch*, which ensures that the default branch only contains finished and approved work.
pages.permissions: Anyone with read access to a repository can create a pull request. {% data reusables.enterprise-accounts.emu-permission-propose %}

pages.title: Creating and deleting branches within your repository
pages.intro: You can create or delete branches directly on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Proposing changes to your work with pull requests
pages.intro: After you add changes to a topic branch or fork, you can open a pull request to ask your collaborators or the repository administrator to review your changes before merging them into the project.

pages.title: Keeping your pull request in sync with the base branch
pages.intro: After you open a pull request, you can update the head branch, which contains your changes, with any changes that have been made in the base branch.
pages.permissions: People with write permissions to the repository to which the head branch of the pull request belongs can update the head branch with changes that have been made in the base branch.

pages.title: Requesting a pull request review
pages.intro: After you create a pull request, you can ask a specific person to review the changes you've proposed. If you're an organization member, you can also request a specific team to review your changes.

pages.title: Using query parameters to create a pull request
pages.intro: Use query parameters to create custom URLs to open pull requests with pre-populated fields.

pages.title: About pull request reviews
pages.intro: Reviews allow collaborators to comment on the changes proposed in pull requests, approve the changes, or request further changes before the pull request is merged. Repository administrators can require that all pull requests are approved before being merged.

pages.title: Approving a pull request with required reviews
pages.intro: If your repository requires reviews, pull requests must have a specific number of approving reviews from people with _write_ or _admin_ permissions in the repository before they can be merged.

pages.title: Checking out pull requests locally
pages.intro: When someone sends you a pull request from a fork or branch of your repository, you can merge it locally to resolve a merge conflict or to test and verify the changes before merging on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.
pages.permissions: Anyone with write access to a repository can pull a remote pull request down locally.

pages.title: Commenting on a pull request
pages.intro: After you open a pull request in a repository, collaborators or team members can comment on the comparison of files between the two specified branches, or leave general comments on the project as a whole.

pages.title: Dismissing a pull request review
pages.intro: If your repository requires reviews, you can dismiss pull request reviews that are no longer valid or are unable to be approved by the reviewer.

pages.title: Filtering files in a pull request
pages.intro: To help you quickly review changes in a large pull request, you can filter changed files.

pages.title: Finding changed methods and functions in a pull request
pages.intro: You can quickly find proposed changes to a method or function in a pull request in *.go*, *.js*, *.ts*, *.py*, *.php*, and *.rb* files.

pages.title: Incorporating feedback in your pull request
pages.intro: When reviewers suggest changes in a pull request, you can automatically incorporate the changes into the pull request or open an issue to track out-of-scope suggestions.

pages.title: Reviewing changes in pull requests
pages.intro: After a pull request has been opened, you can review and discuss the set of proposed changes.

pages.title: Reviewing dependency changes in a pull request
pages.intro: If a pull request contains changes to dependencies, you can view a summary of what has changed and whether there are known vulnerabilities in any of the dependencies.

pages.title: Reviewing proposed changes in a pull request
pages.intro: In a pull request, you can review and discuss commits, changed files, and the differences (or "diff") between the files in the base and compare branches.

pages.title: Viewing a pull request review
pages.intro: You can view all of the comments made in a single pull request review.

pages.title: About forks
pages.intro: A fork is a copy of a repository that you manage. Forks let you make changes to a project without affecting the original repository. You can fetch updates from or submit changes to the original repository with pull requests.

pages.title: Allowing changes to a pull request branch created from a fork
pages.intro: For greater collaboration, you can allow commits on branches you've created from forks owned by your user account.
pages.permissions: People with push access to the upstream repository of a fork owned by a user account can commit to the forked branches.

pages.title: Configuring a remote for a fork
pages.intro: You must configure a remote that points to the upstream repository in Git to [sync changes you make in a fork](/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/syncing-a-fork) with the original repository. This also allows you to sync changes made in the original repository with the fork.

pages.title: Working with forks
pages.intro: Forks are often used in open source development on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Merging an upstream repository into your fork
pages.intro: If you don't have push (write) access to an upstream repository, then you can pull commits from that repository into your own fork.

pages.title: Syncing a fork
pages.intro: Sync a fork of a repository to keep it up-to-date with the upstream repository.

pages.title: What happens to forks when a repository is deleted or changes visibility?
pages.intro: Deleting your repository or changing its visibility affects that repository's forks.

pages.title: About commits
pages.intro: You can save small groups of meaningful changes as commits.

pages.title: Changing a commit message
pages.intro: If a commit message contains unclear, incorrect, or sensitive information, you can amend it locally and push a new commit with a new message to {% data variables.product.product_name %}. You can also change a commit message to add missing information.

pages.title: Creating a commit on behalf of an organization
pages.intro: You can create commits on behalf of an organization by adding a  trailer to the commit's message. Commits attributed to an organization include an `on-behalf-of` badge on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Creating a commit with multiple authors
pages.intro: You can attribute a commit to more than one author by adding one or more `Co-authored-by` trailers to the commit's message. Co-authored commits are visible on {% data variables.product.product_name %}{% ifversion ghes or ghae %} and can be included in the profile contributions graph and the repository's statistics{% endif %}.

pages.title: Committing changes to your project
pages.intro: You can manage code changes in a repository by grouping work into commits.

pages.title: Commit exists on GitHub but not in my local clone
pages.intro: Sometimes a commit will be viewable on {% data variables.product.product_name %}, but will not exist in your local clone of the repository.

pages.title: Why are my commits linked to the wrong user?
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.product_name %} uses the email address in the commit header to link the commit to a GitHub user. If your commits are being linked to another user, or not linked to a user at all, you may need to change your local Git configuration settings{% ifversion not ghae %}, add an email address to your account email settings, or do both{% endif %}.

pages.title: Commit branch and tag labels
pages.intro: You can easily see what branch a commit is in by looking at the labels beneath the commit on the commit page.

pages.title: Comparing commits
pages.intro: You can compare the state of your repository across branches, tags, commits, forks, and dates.

pages.title: Differences between commit views
pages.intro: You might observe differences in commit history depending on the chosen viewing method.

pages.title: Pull requests
pages.intro: Learn how to commit changes to a project and use pull requests to collaborate with others.

pages.title: About archiving content and data on GitHub
pages.intro: You can archive content and data on {% data variables.product.product_name %} for other people to view and reference.

pages.title: Archiving repositories
pages.intro: You can archive a repository to make it read-only for all users and indicate that it's no longer actively maintained. You can also unarchive repositories that have been archived.

pages.title: Backing up a repository
pages.intro: You can use{% ifversion ghes or ghae %} Git and{% endif %} the API {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}or a third-party tool {% endif %}to back up your repository.

pages.title: Archiving a GitHub repository
pages.intro: You can archive, back up, and cite your work using {% data variables.product.product_name %}, the API, or third-party tools and services.

pages.title: Referencing and citing content
pages.intro: You can use third-party tools to cite and reference content on GitHub.

pages.title: About merge methods on GitHub
pages.intro: You can allow contributors with push access to your repository to merge their pull requests on {% data variables.product.product_location %} with different merge options or enforce a specific merge method for all of your repository's pull requests.

pages.title: Configuring commit rebasing for pull requests
pages.intro: You can enforce, allow, or disable commit rebasing for all pull request merges on {% data variables.product.product_location %} in your repository.

pages.title: Configuring commit squashing for pull requests
pages.intro: You can enforce, allow, or disable commit squashing for all pull request merges on {% data variables.product.product_location %} in your repository.

pages.title: Configuring pull request merges
pages.intro: You can configure pull request merges on {% data variables.product.product_location %} to match your workflow and preferences for managing Git history.

pages.title: Managing auto-merge for pull requests in your repository
pages.intro: You can allow or disallow auto-merge for pull requests in your repository.
pages.permissions: People with maintainer permissions can manage auto-merge for pull requests in a repository.

pages.title: Managing suggestions to update pull request branches
pages.intro: You can give users the ability to always update a pull request branch when it is not up to date with the base branch.
pages.permissions: People with maintainer permissions can enable or disable the setting to suggest updating pull request branches.

pages.title: Managing the automatic deletion of branches
pages.intro: You can have head branches automatically deleted after pull requests are merged in your repository.

pages.title: Using a merge queue
pages.intro: You can increase development velocity by enabling merge queues for pull requests in your repository.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions can configure merge queues for pull requests targeting selected branches of a repository.

pages.title: About protected branches
pages.intro: You can protect important branches by setting branch protection rules, which define whether collaborators can delete or force push to the branch and set requirements for any pushes to the branch, such as passing status checks or a linear commit history.

pages.title: Defining the mergeability of pull requests
pages.intro: You can require pull requests to pass a set of checks before they can be merged. For example, you can block pull requests that don't pass status checks or require that pull requests have a specific number of approving reviews before they can be merged.

pages.title: Managing a branch protection rule
pages.intro: You can create a branch protection rule to enforce certain workflows for one or more branches, such as requiring an approving review or passing status checks for all pull requests merged into the protected branch.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions to a repository can manage branch protection rules.

pages.title: Troubleshooting required status checks
pages.intro: You can check for common errors and resolve issues with required status checks.

pages.title: Configuring branches and merges in your repository
pages.intro: You can manage branches in your repository, configure the way branches are merged in your repository, and protect important branches by defining the mergeability of pull requests.

pages.title: Changing the default branch
pages.intro: If you have more than one branch in your repository, you can configure any branch as the default branch.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions to a repository can change the default branch for the repository.

pages.title: Deleting and restoring branches in a pull request
pages.intro: If you have write access in a repository, you can delete branches that are associated with closed or merged pull requests. You cannot delete branches that are associated with open pull requests.

pages.title: Managing branches in your repository
pages.intro: Whenever you propose a change in Git, you [create a new branch](/articles/creating-and-deleting-branches-within-your-repository/). Branch management is an important part of the Git workflow. After some time, your list of branches may grow, so it's a good idea to delete merged or stale branches.

pages.title: Renaming a branch
pages.intro: You can change the name of a branch in a repository.
pages.permissions: People with write permissions to a repository can rename a branch in the repository unless it is the [default branch](/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/about-branches#about-the-default-branch){% ifversion fpt or ghec or ghes > 3.3 %} or a [protected branch](/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/defining-the-mergeability-of-pull-requests/about-protected-branches){% endif %}. People with admin permissions can rename the default branch{% ifversion fpt or ghec or ghes > 3.3 %} and protected branches{% endif %}.

pages.title: Viewing branches in your repository
pages.intro: Branches are central to collaboration on {% data variables.product.product_name %}, and the best way to view them is the branches page.

pages.title: About repositories
pages.intro: A repository contains all of your project's files and each file's revision history. You can discuss and manage your project's work within the repository.

pages.title: Cloning a repository
pages.intro: When you create a repository on {% data variables.product.product_location %}, it exists as a remote repository. You can clone your repository to create a local copy on your computer and sync between the two locations.

pages.title: Creating a new repository
pages.intro: You can create a new repository on your personal account or any organization where you have sufficient permissions.

pages.title: Creating a repository from a template
pages.intro: You can generate a new repository with the same directory structure and files as an existing repository.

pages.title: Creating a template repository
pages.intro: You can make an existing repository a template, so you and others can generate new repositories with the same directory structure{% ifversion fpt or ghae or ghes or ghec %}, branches,{% endif %} and files.
pages.permissions: Anyone with admin permissions to a repository can make the repository a template.

pages.title: Creating an issues-only repository
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.product_name %} does not provide issues-only access permissions, but you can accomplish this using a second repository which contains only the issues.

pages.title: Deleting a repository
pages.intro: You can delete any repository or fork if you're either an organization owner or have admin permissions for the repository or fork. Deleting a forked repository does not delete the upstream repository.

pages.title: Duplicating a repository
pages.intro: To maintain a mirror of a repository without forking it, you can run a special clone command, then mirror-push to the new repository.

pages.title: Creating and managing repositories
pages.intro: You can create a repository on {% data variables.product.product_name %} to store and collaborate on your project's files, then manage the repository's name and location.

pages.title: Renaming a repository
pages.intro: You can rename a repository if you're either an organization owner or have admin permissions for the repository.

pages.title: Restoring a deleted repository
pages.intro: You can restore some deleted repositories to recover their contents.

pages.title: Transferring a repository
pages.intro: You can transfer repositories to other users or organization accounts.

pages.title: Troubleshooting cloning errors
pages.intro: If you're having trouble cloning a repository, check these common errors.

pages.title: Repositories
pages.intro: Learn to use and manage the repositories that allow you to store and collaborate on your project's code.

pages.title: About CITATION files
pages.intro: You can add a CITATION file to your repository to help users correctly cite your software.

pages.title: About code owners
pages.intro: You can use a CODEOWNERS file to define individuals or teams that are responsible for code in a repository.

pages.title: About READMEs
pages.intro: You can add a README file to your repository to tell other people why your project is useful, what they can do with your project, and how they can use it.

pages.title: About repository languages
pages.intro: The files and directories within a repository determine the languages that make up the repository. You can view a repository's languages to get a quick overview of the repository.

pages.title: Classifying your repository with topics
pages.intro: To help other people find and contribute to your project, you can add topics to your repository related to your project's intended purpose, subject area, affinity groups, or other important qualities.

pages.title: Customizing your repository's social media preview
pages.intro: You can customize the image displayed on social media platforms when someone links to your repository.

pages.title: Displaying a sponsor button in your repository
pages.intro: You can add a sponsor button in your repository to increase the visibility of funding options for your open source project.

pages.title: Customizing your repository
pages.intro: You can choose the way your repository appears by customizing your repository.

pages.title: Licensing a repository
pages.intro: Public repositories on GitHub are often used to share open source software. For your repository to truly be open source, you'll need to license it so that others are free to use, change, and distribute the software.

pages.title: Disabling issues
pages.intro: You may wish to turn issues off for your repository if you do not accept contributions or bug reports.

pages.title: Disabling project boards in a repository
pages.intro: Repository administrators can turn off project boards for a repository if you or your team manages work differently.

pages.title: Enabling or disabling GitHub Discussions for a repository
pages.intro: You can use {% data variables.product.prodname_discussions %} in a repository as a place for your community to have conversations, ask questions, and post answers without scoping work in an issue.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions to a repository can enable {% data variables.product.prodname_discussions %} for the repository.

pages.title: Enabling features for your repository
pages.intro: You can enable, configure, and disable optional features for your repository.

pages.title: Managing GitHub Actions settings for a repository
pages.intro: You can disable or configure {% data variables.product.prodname_actions %} for a specific repository.

pages.title: Managing security and analysis settings for your repository
pages.intro: You can control features that secure and analyze the code in your project on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions to a repository can manage security and analysis settings for the repository.

pages.title: Managing your repositorys settings and features
pages.intro: You can customize your repository, enable or disable optional features for your repository, and manage your repositorys settings.

pages.title: About email notifications for pushes to your repository
pages.intro: You can choose to automatically send email notifications to a specific email address when anyone pushes to the repository.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions in a repository can enable email notifications for pushes to your repository.

pages.title: Configuring autolinks to reference external resources
pages.intro: You can add autolinks to external resources like JIRA issues and Zendesk tickets to help streamline your workflow.

pages.title: Enabling anonymous Git read access for a repository
pages.intro: As a repository administrator, you can enable or disable anonymous Git read access for public repositories that meet certain requirements.

pages.title: Managing repository settings
pages.intro: You can choose the way your repository functions by managing repository settings.

pages.title: Managing Git LFS objects in archives of your repository
pages.shortTitle: Managing {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %} objects in archives
pages.intro: You can choose whether {% data variables.large_files.product_name_long %} ({% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %}) objects are included in source code archives, such as ZIP files and tarballs, {% data variables.product.product_name %} creates for your repository.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions for a repository can manage whether {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %} objects are included in archives of the repository.

pages.title: Managing teams and people with access to your repository
pages.intro: You can see everyone who has access to your repository and adjust permissions.
pages.permissions: People with admin access to a repository can manage teams and people with access to a repository.

pages.title: Managing the forking policy for your repository
pages.intro: You can allow or prevent the forking of a specific private{% ifversion ghae or ghes or ghec %} or internal{% endif %} repository owned by an organization.
pages.permissions: People with admin permissions for a repository can manage the forking policy for the repository.

pages.title: Setting repository visibility
pages.intro: You can choose who can view your repository.

pages.title: About releases
pages.intro: You can create a release to package software, along with release notes and links to binary files, for other people to use.

pages.title: Automatically generated release notes
pages.intro: You can automatically generate release notes for your GitHub releases
pages.permissions: Repository collaborators and people with write access to a repository can generate and customize automated release notes for a release.

pages.title: Automation for release forms with query parameters
pages.intro: To quickly create releases by auto-populating the new release form with customized information, you can add query parameters to the URL for the release form page.

pages.title: Comparing releases
pages.intro: You can compare release tags to see changes to your repository between different releases.
pages.permissions: People with read access to a repository can view and compare releases.

pages.title: Releasing projects on GitHub
pages.intro: You can create a release to package software, release notes, and binary files for other people to download.

pages.title: Linking to releases
pages.intro: You can share every release you create on GitHub with a unique URL.

pages.title: Managing releases in a repository
pages.intro: You can create releases to bundle and deliver iterations of a project to users.
pages.permissions: Repository collaborators and people with write access to a repository can create, edit, and delete a release.

pages.title: Searching a repository's releases
pages.intro: You can use keywords, tags, and other qualifiers to search for particular releases in a repository.
pages.permissions: Anyone with read access to a repository can search that repository's releases.

pages.title: Viewing your repository's releases and tags
pages.intro: You can view the chronological history of your repository by release name or tag version number.

pages.title: About repository graphs
pages.intro: Repository graphs help you view and analyze data for your repository.

pages.title: Analyzing changes to a repository's content
pages.intro: You can see the changes to the content of a repository by analyzing the repository's commits, commit frequency, and content additions and deletions.

pages.title: Viewing activity and data for your repository
pages.intro: Gain insight into your repository by viewing activity and data.

pages.title: Understanding connections between repositories
pages.intro: You can better understand the connections that exist between repositories by viewing a repository's network and forks and the projects that depend on the repository.

pages.title: Viewing a project's contributors
pages.intro: You can see who contributed commits to a repository{% ifversion fpt or ghec %} and its dependencies{% endif %}.

pages.title: Viewing a summary of repository activity
pages.intro: You can view an overview of a repository's pull request, issue, and commit activity.

pages.title: Viewing deployment activity for your repository
pages.intro: You can view information about deployments for your entire repository or a specific pull request.

pages.title: Viewing traffic to a repository
pages.intro: Anyone with push access to a repository can view its traffic, including full clones (not fetches), visitors from the past 14 days, referring sites, and popular content in the traffic graph.
pages.product: This repository insights graph is available in public repositories with {% data variables.product.prodname_free_user %} and {% data variables.product.prodname_free_team %} for organizations, and in public and private repositories with {% data variables.product.prodname_pro %}, {% data variables.product.prodname_team %}, and {% data variables.product.prodname_ghe_cloud %}.{% ifversion fpt %} For more information, see "[About repository graphs](/articles/about-repository-graphs)" and "[{% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}'s products](/articles/github-s-products)."{% endif %}

pages.title: Working with files
pages.intro: Learn how to manage and use files in repositories.

pages.title: Adding a file to a repository
pages.intro: You can upload and commit an existing file to a repository on {% data variables.product.product_name %} or by using the command line.

pages.title: Creating new files
pages.intro: You can create new files directly on {% data variables.product.product_name %} in any repository you have write access to.

pages.title: Customizing how changed files appear on GitHub
pages.intro: To keep certain files from displaying in diffs by default, or counting toward the repository language, you can mark them with the `linguist-generated` attribute in a *.gitattributes* file.

pages.title: Deleting files in a repository
pages.intro: You can delete an individual file{% ifversion fpt or ghes > 3.0 or ghec %} or an entire directory{% endif %} in your repository on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.
pages.permissions: People with write permissions can delete files{% ifversion fpt or ghes > 3.0 or ghec %} or directories{% endif %} in a repository.

pages.title: Editing files
pages.intro: You can edit files directly on {% data variables.product.product_name %} in any of your repositories using the file editor.

pages.title: Managing files
pages.intro: You can create, edit, move, and delete files in a repository, directly on {% data variables.product.product_name %} or on the command line.

pages.title: Moving a file to a new location
pages.intro: You can move a file to a different directory on {% data variables.product.product_name %} or by using the command line.

pages.title: Renaming a file
pages.intro: You can rename any file in your repository directly in {% data variables.product.product_name %} or by using the command line.

pages.title: About Git Large File Storage
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.product_name %} limits the size of files allowed in repositories. To track files beyond this limit, you can use {% data variables.large_files.product_name_long %}.

pages.title: About large files on GitHub
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.product_name %} limits the size of files you can track in regular Git repositories. Learn how to track or remove files that are beyond the limit.

pages.title: About storage and bandwidth usage
pages.intro: {% data reusables.large_files.free-storage-bandwidth-amount %}

pages.title: Collaboration with Git Large File Storage
pages.intro: With {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %} enabled, you'll be able to fetch, modify, and push large files just as you would expect with any file that Git manages. However, a user that doesn't have {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %} will experience a different workflow.

pages.title: Configuring Git Large File Storage
pages.intro: Once [{% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %} is installed](/articles/installing-git-large-file-storage/), you need to associate it with a large file in your repository.

pages.title: Managing large files
pages.intro: You can manage large files with Git Large File Storage.

pages.title: Installing Git Large File Storage
pages.intro: In order to use {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %}, you'll need to download and install a new program that's separate from Git.

pages.title: Moving a file in your repository to Git Large File Storage
pages.intro: If you've set up {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %}, and you have an existing file in your repository that needs to be tracked in {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %}, you need to first remove it from your repository.
pages.shortTitle: Move a file to Git LFS

pages.title: Removing files from Git Large File Storage
pages.intro: If you've set up {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %} for your repository, you can remove all files or a subset of files from {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %}.

pages.title: Resolving Git Large File Storage upload failures
pages.intro: If your {% data variables.large_files.product_name_short %} files didn't upload properly, you can take several steps to troubleshoot the upload error.

pages.title: Getting permanent links to files
pages.intro: When viewing a file on {% data variables.product.product_location %}, you can press the "y" key to update the URL to a permalink to the exact version of the file you see.

pages.title: Using files
pages.intro: You can navigate and track changes in the code in your files.

pages.title: Navigating code on GitHub
pages.intro: You can understand the relationships within and across repositories by navigating code directly in {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Viewing a file
pages.intro: You can view raw file content or trace changes to lines in a file and discover how parts of the file evolved over time.
pages.shortTitle: View files and track file changes

pages.title: Working with non-code files
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.product_name %} supports rendering and diffing in a number of non-code file formats.

pages.title: Basics of authentication
pages.intro: Learn about the different ways to authenticate with some examples.

pages.title: Best practices for integrators
pages.intro: Build an app that reliably interacts with the {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}{% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}{% else %}{% data variables.product.product_name %}{% endif %} API and provides the best experience for your users.

pages.title: Building a CI server
pages.intro: Build your own CI system using the Status API.

pages.title: Delivering deployments
pages.intro: Using the Deployments REST API, you can build custom tooling that interacts with your server and a third-party app.

pages.title: Discovering resources for a user
pages.intro: Learn how to find the repositories and organizations that your app can access for a user in a reliable way for your authenticated requests to the REST API.

pages.title: Getting started with the Checks API
pages.intro: The Check Runs API enables you to build GitHub Apps that run powerful checks against code changes in a repository. You can create apps that perform continuous integration, code linting, or code scanning services and provide detailed feedback on commits.

pages.title: Getting started with the Git Database API
pages.intro: The Git Database API gives you access to read and write raw Git objects to your Git database on {% data variables.product.product_name %} and to list and update your references (branch heads and tags).

pages.title: Getting started with the REST API
pages.intro: Learn the foundations for using the REST API, starting with authentication and some endpoint examples.

pages.title: Guides
pages.intro: Learn about getting started with the REST API, authentication, and how to use the REST API for a variety of tasks.

pages.title: Rendering data as graphs
pages.intro: Learn how to visualize the programming languages from your repository using the D3.js library and Ruby Octokit.

pages.title: Traversing with pagination
pages.intro: Explore how to use pagination to manage your responses with some examples using the Search API.

pages.title: Working with comments
pages.intro: Using the REST API, you can access and manage comments in your pull requests, issues, or commits.

pages.title: GitHub REST API
pages.intro: To create integrations, retrieve data, and automate your workflows, build with the {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} REST API.

pages.title: API previews
pages.intro: You can use API previews to try out new features and provide feedback before these features become official.

pages.title: Endpoints available for GitHub Apps
pages.intro: Your app can make requests to the following REST endpoints.

pages.title: REST API overview
pages.intro: Learn about resources, libraries, previews and troubleshooting for {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}'s REST API.

pages.title: Libraries
pages.intro: You can use the official Octokit library and other third-party libraries to extend and simplify how you use the {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}{% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}{% else %}{% data variables.product.product_name %}{% endif %} API.

pages.title: Media types
pages.intro: Learn about media types for specifying the format of the data you want to consume.

pages.title: OpenAPI description
pages.intro: The {% data variables.product.product_name %} REST API is fully described in an OpenAPI 3.0 compliant document.

pages.title: Other authentication methods
pages.intro: You can use basic authentication for testing in a non-production environment.

pages.title: Resources in the REST API
pages.intro: Learn how to navigate the resources provided by the {% ifversion fpt or ghec %}{% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %}{% else %}{% data variables.product.product_name %}{% endif %} API.

pages.title: Troubleshooting
pages.intro: Learn how to resolve the most common problems people encounter in the REST API.

pages.title: Actions
pages.intro: With the Actions API, you can manage and control {% data variables.product.prodname_actions %} for an organization or repository.

pages.title: Activity
pages.intro: The Activity API allows you to list events and feeds and manage notifications, starring, and watching for the authenticated user.

pages.title: Apps
pages.intro: The GitHub Apps API enables you to retrieve the information about the installation as well as specific information about GitHub Apps.

pages.title: Billing
pages.intro: With the Billing API, you can monitor the charges and usage {% data variables.product.prodname_actions %} and {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} for a user or organization.

pages.title: Branches
pages.intro: The branches API allows you to modify branches and their protection settings.

pages.title: Checks
pages.intro: With the Checks API, you can build {% data variables.product.prodname_github_apps %} that run powerful checks against the code changes in a repository.

pages.title: Code scanning
pages.intro: The Code Scanning API enables you to retrieve and update the code scanning alerts and analyses from a repository.

pages.title: Codes of conduct
pages.intro: The Codes of Conduct API lets you to retrieve the information about a particular repository's code of conduct.

pages.title: Codespaces
pages.intro: The {% data variables.product.prodname_codespaces %} API enables you to manage your codespaces using the REST API.

pages.title: Collaborators
pages.intro: The collaborators API allows you to add, invite, and remove collaborators from a repository.

pages.title: Commits
pages.intro: The commits API allows you to list, view, and compare commits in a repository. You can also interact with commit comments and commit statuses.

pages.title: Dependabot
pages.intro: With the {% data variables.product.prodname_dependabot %} Secrets API, you can manage and control {% data variables.product.prodname_dependabot %} secrets for an organization or repository.

pages.title: Deployments
pages.intro: The deployments API allows you to create and delete deploy keys, deployments, and deployment environments.

pages.title: Emojis
pages.intro: With the Emojis API, you can list and view all the available emojis to use in {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: GitHub Enterprise administration
pages.intro: You can use these endpoints to administer your enterprise. Among the tasks you can perform with this API are many relating to GitHub Actions.

pages.title: Gists
pages.intro: The Gists API enables the authorized user to list, create, update and delete the public gists on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Git database
pages.intro: The Git Database API enables you to read and write raw Git objects to your Git database on {% data variables.product.product_name %} and to list and update Git references (branch heads and tags).

pages.title: Gitignore
pages.intro: The Gitignore API fetches `.gitignore` templates that can be used to ignore files and directories.

pages.title: Reference
pages.intro: View reference documentation to learn about the resources available in the GitHub REST API.

pages.title: Interactions
pages.intro: With the Interactions API, people with owner or admin access can set the interaction limit for the users in their organizations and repositories.

pages.title: Issues
pages.intro: The Issues API enables you to view and manage issues, including issue assignees, comments, labels, and milestones.

pages.title: Licenses
pages.intro: The Licenses API lets you to retrieve popular open source licenses and information about a particular project's license file.

pages.title: Markdown
pages.intro: The Markdown API enables you to render a markdown document as an HTML page or as raw text.

pages.title: Meta
pages.intro: The Meta API returns meta information about {% data variables.product.product_name %} including the IP addresses of {% data variables.product.product_name %} services.

pages.title: Metrics
pages.intro: The repository metrics API allows you to retrieve community profile, statistics, and traffic for your repository.

pages.title: Migrations
pages.intro: The Migration API lets you migrate the repositories and users of your  organization from {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom_the_website %} to {% data variables.product.prodname_ghe_server %}.

pages.title: Organizations
pages.intro: The Organizations API gives you access to control and manage all your {% data variables.product.product_name %} organizations.

pages.title: Packages
pages.intro: With the {% data variables.product.prodname_registry %} API, you can manage packages for your {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} repositories and organizations.

pages.title: Pages
pages.intro: The GitHub Pages API allows you to interact with GitHub Pages sites and build information.

pages.title: Permissions required for GitHub Apps
pages.intro: You can find the required permissions for each {% data variables.product.prodname_github_app %}-compatible endpoint.

pages.title: Projects
pages.intro: The Projects API lets you create, list, update, delete and customize projects in a repository.

pages.title: Pulls
pages.intro: The Pulls API allows you to list, view, edit, create, and even merge pull requests.

pages.title: Rate limit
pages.intro: With the Rate Limit API, you can check the current rate limit status of various REST APIs.

pages.title: Reactions
pages.intro: The Reactions API enables you to create, list and delete the reactions on comments.

pages.title: Releases
pages.intro: The releases API allows you to create, modify, and delete releases and release assets.

pages.title: Repositories
pages.intro: The Repos API allows to create, manage and control the workflow of public and private {% data variables.product.product_name %} repositories.

pages.title: SCIM
pages.intro: You can control and manage your {% data variables.product.product_name %} organization members access using SCIM API.

pages.title: Search
pages.intro: The {% data variables.product.product_name %} Search API lets you to search for the specific item efficiently.

pages.title: Secret scanning
pages.intro: To retrieve and update the secret alerts from a private repository, you can use Secret Scanning API.

pages.title: Teams
pages.intro: With the Teams API, you can create and manage teams in your {% data variables.product.product_name %} organization.

pages.title: Users
pages.intro: The Users API allows to get public and private information about the authenticated user.

pages.title: Webhooks
pages.intro: The webhooks API allows you to create and manage webhooks for your repositories.

pages.title: About searching on GitHub
pages.intro: Our integrated search covers the many repositories, users, and lines of code on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Enabling GitHub.com repository search from your private enterprise environment
pages.intro: You can connect your personal accounts on {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom_the_website %} and your private {% data variables.product.prodname_enterprise %} environment to search for content in certain {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom_the_website %} repositories{% ifversion fpt or ghec %} from your private environment{% else %} from {% data variables.product.product_name %}{% endif %}.

pages.title: Getting started with searching on GitHub
pages.intro: You can use a wide range of syntax to search {% data variables.product.product_name %}. You can adjust the scope of your search, build and troubleshoot queries, and sort search results with qualifiers.

pages.intro: When searching {% data variables.product.product_name %}, you can construct queries that match specific numbers and words.

pages.intro: You can search for a file in a repository using the file finder. To search for a file in multiple repositories on {% data variables.product.product_name %}, use the [`filename` code search qualifier](/search-github/searching-on-github/searching-code#search-by-filename).

pages.title: Searching commits
pages.intro: You can search for commits on {% data variables.product.product_name %} and narrow the results using these commit search qualifiers in any combination.

pages.title: Searching discussions
pages.intro: You can search for discussions on {% data variables.product.product_name %} and narrow the results using search qualifiers.

pages.title: Searching for packages
pages.intro: You can search for packages on {% data variables.product.product_name %} and narrow the results using search qualifiers.

pages.title: Searching for repositories
pages.intro: You can search for repositories on {% data variables.product.product_name %} and narrow the results using these repository search qualifiers in any combination.

pages.intro: You can search for apps and actions that are available on {% data variables.product.prodname_marketplace %}.

pages.title: Searching issues and pull requests

pages.title: About GitHub Sponsors
pages.intro: {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} allows the developer community to financially support the people and organizations who design, build, and maintain the open source projects they depend on, directly on {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Getting started with GitHub Sponsors
pages.intro: Learn about {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} and how you can get involved as a sponsor or open source contributor.

pages.title: Quickstart for finding contributors to sponsor
pages.intro: Learn some best practices for finding open source contributors to sponsor.

pages.title: GitHub Sponsors guides
pages.intro: Learn how to make the most of {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %}.

pages.title: GitHub Sponsors Documentation
pages.intro: Invest in the open source projects you depend on, support digital infrastructure, and make open source careers possible by sponsoring open source contributors and their projects. Build a {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} profile and receive compensation for your open source work.

pages.title: Configuring webhooks for events in your sponsored account
pages.intro: You can configure webhooks to alert you when you receive new sponsorships or existing sponsors make changes to their sponsorships.

pages.title: Getting started with the Sponsors GraphQL API
pages.intro: Using the GraphQL API, you can build custom integrations to manage or review your sponsorships.

pages.title: Integrating with GitHub Sponsors
pages.intro: As an open source contributor, you can build custom tools to manage your GitHub sponsorships.

pages.title: About GitHub Sponsors for open source contributors
pages.intro: If you provide value to an open source project, you can become a sponsored contributor to receive payments for your work.

pages.title: Contacting your sponsors
pages.intro: You can send an email to your sponsors who have opted in to receive updates about your work.

pages.title: Disabling your GitHub Sponsors account
pages.intro: If you no longer want to participate in {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %}, you can disable your {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} account.

pages.title: Editing your profile details for GitHub Sponsors
pages.intro: You can update the information that potential sponsors see about your work.

pages.title: Receiving sponsorships through GitHub Sponsors
pages.intro: You or your organization can become a sponsored open source contributor to receive payments for your work, update your sponsorship details, and view and contact your sponsors.

pages.title: Managing your payouts from GitHub Sponsors
pages.intro: You can view information about past and future payouts from {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} and edit your bank information.

pages.title: Managing your sponsorship goal
pages.intro: You can set a goal for your sponsored developer or sponsored organization account to help the community understand the impact of sponsoring you.

pages.title: Managing your sponsorship tiers
pages.intro: You can add a new sponsorship tier, or edit or retire an existing tier.

pages.title: Setting up GitHub Sponsors for your organization
pages.intro: Your organization can join {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} to receive payments for your work.
pages.permissions: Organization owners can set up {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} for an organization.

pages.title: Setting up GitHub Sponsors for your user account
pages.intro: You can become a sponsored developer by joining {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %}, completing your sponsored developer profile, creating sponsorship tiers, submitting your bank and tax information, and enabling two-factor authentication for your account on {% data variables.product.product_location %}.

pages.title: Receiving payments from Sponsors for Companies
pages.intro: To accept payments from the Sponsors for Companies service, you must accept some additional terms.

pages.title: Tax information for GitHub Sponsors
pages.intro: Sponsored developers and organizations must submit tax information to {% data variables.product.prodname_dotcom %} and are responsible for evaluating and paying their own taxes.

pages.title: Unpublishing your GitHub Sponsors profile
pages.intro: If you don't have any sponsors, you can unpublish your {% data variables.product.prodname_sponsors %} profile.

pages.title: Viewing your sponsors and sponsorships
pages.intro: You can view and export detailed information and analytics about your sponsors and sponsorships.

pages.title: Attributing sponsorships to your organization
pages.intro: You can attribute the sponsorships paid by one of your organizations to another organization.
pages.permissions: People who are organization owners of both organizations can attribute one organization's sponsorships to another organization.

pages.title: Sponsoring open source contributors
pages.intro: You can sponsor contributors, receive updates on developers and organizations you sponsor, and display a sponsor badge throughout {% data variables.product.product_name %}.

pages.title: Managing your sponsorship
pages.intro: You can manage who can see your sponsorship and whether you receive email updates from the sponsored account.

pages.title: Paying for GitHub Sponsors by invoice
pages.intro: If your company pays {% data variables.product.company_short %} by invoice, you can join the Sponsors for Companies service.

pages.title: Sponsoring an open source contributor
pages.intro: You can make a monthly recurring payment to a developer or organization who designs, creates, or maintains open source projects you depend on.
pages.permissions: Anyone can sponsor accounts on behalf of their own user account. Organization owners and billing managers can sponsor accounts on behalf of their organization.

pages.title: Creating a support ticket
pages.intro: You can use the {% ifversion ghae %}{% data variables.contact.ae_azure_portal %}{% else %}{% data variables.contact.support_portal %}{% endif %} to create a support ticket and speak to {% data variables.contact.github_support %}.

pages.title: Contacting GitHub Support
pages.intro: You can use the {% ifversion ghae %}{% data variables.contact.ae_azure_portal %}{% else %}{% data variables.contact.support_portal %}{% endif %} to contact GitHub Support for help troubleshooting issues you encounter while using GitHub.

pages.title: Providing data to GitHub Support
pages.intro: Since {% data variables.contact.github_support %} doesn't have access to your environment, we sometimes require some additional information from you.

pages.title: Viewing and updating support tickets
pages.intro: You can view your support tickets{% ifversion ghes or ghec %}, collaborate with colleagues on tickets,{% endif %} and respond to {% data variables.contact.github_support %} using the {% data variables.contact.support_portal %}.

pages.title: Working with GitHub Support
pages.intro: GitHub offers different levels of support with each product, including community forum support and limited email support for everyone, full email support for all paid products, and 24/7 email and callback support with a service level agreement (SLA) if your account includes {% data variables.contact.premium_support %}.

pages.title: About GitHub Premium Support
pages.intro: {% data variables.contact.premium_support %} is a paid, supplemental support offering for {% data variables.product.prodname_enterprise %} customers.

pages.title: About GitHub Support
pages.intro: You can contact GitHub Support for help troubleshooting issues you encounter while using GitHub.

pages.title: About ticket priority
pages.intro: You can communicate the severity of your issue and how it is affecting you and your team by setting the priority of your support ticket.

pages.title: GitHub Marketplace support
pages.intro: When you encounter issues using an app in {% data variables.product.prodname_marketplace %}, you can contact the support team for the app.

pages.title: Learning about GitHub Support
